titleStmt.title: Joyfull newes from Captain Marro in Ireland or, His second victory over the rebels, April 18. Shewing in a most true and exact relation, the manner of two glorious battles, never to be forgotten. The first, by the invincible courage, of Captiain [sic] Marro, April 18. Also his parley, and the assault and repulse of Mongarrets army, April 19. The second, by the said Captain Marro, and being seconded by Sir Henry Tichbourn, gave the rebels a great overthrow, with the number of men that were slain in each battle. Also His Majesties message to the House of Peers, April the 22. 1642.
titleStmt.author: Damon, John, 17th cent.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 6 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: JOYFULL NEWES FROM CAPTAIN MARRO IN IRELAND‚ñ™ OR, His ≈øecond victory over the Rebels, April 18.
Shewing in a mo≈øt true and exact Relation, the manner of two Glorious Battles never to be forgotten.
The fir≈øt by the invincible Courage, of Captiain Marro, April, 18. Al≈øo His Parley, and the A≈ø≈øault and Repul≈øe of Mougarrets Army, April 19.
The ≈øecond, by the ≈øaid Captain Marro, and being ≈øeconded by Sir Henry Tichbourn, gave the Rebels a great Overthrow, with the Number of the men that were ≈ølain in each battle.
Al≈øo His Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øage to the Hou≈øe of Peers, April the 22. 1642.

div.head: His Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øage to the Hou≈øe Peers. April. 22. 1642.
div.p: HIs Maje≈øtie having ≈øeene a Printed Paper, entituled, A Que≈øtion an≈øwered how Lawes are to be vnder≈øtood and obedience yeelded; (which Paper He ≈øends together which this Me≈ø≈øage think, fit to re ‚Ä¢ ommend the con≈øideration of it to His Hou≈øe of Peers, that they may u≈øe all po≈øsible care and diligence for the finding out the Authour, and m ‚Ä¢ y give directions to His learned Councell, to proceed again≈øt Him and the Publi≈øhers of it, in ≈øuch a way as ≈øhal be agreable to Law and the cour≈øe of ju≈øtice, as Per≈øons who indeavour to ≈øtir up Sedition again≈øt his Maje≈øtie; And His Maje≈øty doubts not but they will be very ≈øen≈øible how much their own particular Intere≈øt (as well as the Publike government of the Kingdom) is, and mu≈øt be ≈øhaken, if ≈øuch licence ≈øhall be permitted to bold factious ≈øpirits to withdraw His Subjects ≈øtrict obedience from the Laws e≈øtabli≈øhed by ≈øuch Seditious and Trea≈øonable di≈øtinctions. And of Doctrines of this nature, His Maje≈øties doubts not but that their Lord≈øhips will publi≈øh their great di≈ølike, it being growne into frequent Di≈øcour≈øe, and vented in ≈øome Pulpits by tho≈øe de≈øperate turbulent Preachers who are the great Promoters of the di≈øtempers of this time) That human Laws doe not binde the Con≈øcience: which being once beleeved‚ñ™ the civill Government and peace of the Kingdom will be quickly di≈ø≈øolved‚ñ™ His Maje≈øtie ex≈øpects a ≈øpeeche account of their Lord≈øhips exmplary ju≈øtice upon the Authors and publi≈øhers of this Paper.

div.head: MORE GLORIOUS, JOYFULL, AND RENOWNED NEWES, FROM IRELAND.
div.p: IF there were ever found deadly enemies to true Chri≈øtian Religion, they are now found out in Ireland; that Mother of all treachery, and Nur≈øe of Trea≈øon, as may appear by this en≈øuing Relation following.

Upon the 17. day of this pre≈øent Moneth, the Lord Montgarret, and the great
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
Rebell Mac-Davo, drew their forces together to the number of 14000, intending to give battle again≈øt Captain Marro; by rea≈øon he had be≈øieged the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Bellon in the Neweries: they having intelligence, that he was but 900 ≈øtrong, having with them but only three peeces of Ordnance, he had given three great a≈ø≈øaults again≈øt the afore≈øaid Ca≈øtle, and mounted his Ordnance in three ≈øeverall places, being furni≈øhed with Cannoncers of great note; Upon the 18. day of this month he gave the fourth A≈ø≈øault again≈øt the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle; where after three hours fight, the Ca≈øtle yeelded, putting all that were therin to the ≈øword, being in number 300. he then entred the Ca≈øtle, taking great‚ñ™ ≈øtore of good pillage and ammunition, planting his three Pieces on the ≈øaid Ca≈øtle, having intelligence that the Lord Mongarret, and Mack-Davo were intended to give battle again≈øt them, being 7. miles off. Sir Henry Tichbourn having received a Letter from Captain Marro that he had takeu the Ca≈øtle, and that
the afore≈øaid Rebels were re≈øolved to a≈ø≈øault him, ha≈øted to him with all ≈øpeed, with 1700. men, and being within half a mile of the Ca≈øtle, cau≈øed his Drums to beat up, Captain Marro hearing the ≈øame, ≈øent out Lieutenant John≈øon with 200. to meet them, to know what they were, and approaching neer them, Sir Henry ≈øent to him, to tell him what his intents were, that he was re≈øolved to withdraw back til he ≈øaw the Enemy approach neer the Ca≈øtle; wherupon Lieutenant John≈øon returned back to his Captain, relating to him the policy of Sir Henry, this was upon the 19. of this month, in the morning; and about two of the clock in the afternoon, the Rebels marched towards the Ca≈øtle, be≈øieging it, and having ≈øet their men in four Battalions, began to play again≈øt the Ca≈øtle, Captain Marro an≈øwering them couragiou≈øly, playing with his Ordnance ≈øo thick again≈øt them, that there were ≈ølain of the Rebels in the fir≈øt fiering 300. men, of our ≈øide 18. after ≈øome ce≈ø≈øation they fell too't again, the battle
continuing very hot, being doubtfull on both ≈øides, till Sir Henry approached and fell on ≈øending 200. men to give battle again≈øt the Enemy on the left ≈ølanck, if they had attempted to pa≈ø≈øe by on the right ≈ølank, of tho≈øe that were in fight, he ≈øent ≈øecretly by the Hils (where there was a hollow di≈øtance) 500. men to charge them in their Front, which amazed the Enemy much, he him≈øelfe falling on with the re≈øt of the Army, Captain Marro ≈øtill playing again≈øt them with mo≈øt unheard of courage, who after the ≈øpace of 13. houres fight, the enemy was forced to retire, Sir Henry and Captaine Marro hath al≈øo taken 5. other Ca≈øtles in the Neweries, and put many of the Rebels to the Sword, the la≈øt weeke, it is thought they will begin with the great Ca≈øtle called Newery Ca≈øtle the next.

closer.dateline: From our Quarters in the Neweries, Aprill the 21. 1642.

div.head: More exceeding true and ioyfull Newes from Ireland.
div.p: ON the 14. of this month, I received your Letter, being ≈øorry to hear ≈øuch bad news from you; and wheras you writ to me, to ≈øend you word how pa≈ø≈øages went with us here, I thought it convenient, to ≈øend you the≈øe Occurrences, following.

Vpon the 17. of this pre≈øent month, there was a great and bloudy battell in the Neweries, fought between 3000. men of our ≈øide, under the Command of Sir Henrie Tichbourn, Sir Charles Coot, and Captain Marro, again≈øt 10000. of the Rebels, conducted by the great Rebel Mondormo, and after a long and tedious Battel, they put the Rebels to flight, kild 2000. of them, and wounded the Lord Mondormo: of our ≈øide were ≈ølain 400. they are intended to fight a pitcht Battel about the 25. day of this month. We had tydings brought to our Army, April 12. that Sir Philomy O-Neal hath got a great army, intending to give Battel again≈øt us in the Neweries. Captain Marro
received a Letter from Colonel Gore, in the North of Ireland, relating how they had defeated ≈øix Regiments of the rebels forces, but my Lord of Mun≈øter hath had ≈øome lo≈ø≈øe there.

closer.signed: So I re≈øt your loving Brother J. Gilbert.

postscript.p: Ordered by the Lords and Commons in Parliament, that the Lord Howard of Char, ≈øhall attend upon the King, and pre≈øent ≈øome Rea≈øons unto His Maje≈øty.
